title: 103_hr3582
content: SECTION 1. AUTOMATIC ELIGIBILITY OF HEAD START PARTICIPANTS. Section 9(b)(6) of the National School Lunch Act is amended to include participants in a Head Start program as eligible for benefits. Participants in a Head Start program are now eligible for benefits under the National School Lunch Act. This includes enrollment or participation in a Head Start program as specified in the Head Start Act. The Child and Adult Care Food Program is addressed in Section 2. The Child and Adult Care Food Program is addressed in Section 2. The definition of an institution under the National School Lunch Act is amended to include organizations serving children meeting income eligibility criteria for free or reduced-price meals. Additional reimbursement provisions for family or group day care home sponsoring organizations are also modified. The Child and Adult Care Food Program is amended to set enhanced reimbursement levels for sponsors serving providers in rural or economically disadvantaged areas. Reimbursement levels will be $10 higher than the standard rate and adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index. Expansion funds can now be used for outreach to unlicensed organizations. Expansion funds can be used for outreach to unlicensed day care homes to help them become licensed. A sponsoring organization can receive funds for up to 50 day care homes. Additionally, the Child and Adult Care Food Program is amended to provide enhanced reimbursement levels for sponsors in rural or economically disadvantaged areas. Medicaid and WIC information will be provided to State agencies for program implementation. The materials will inform State agencies about the availability and importance of the Medicaid program for children from low-income families, as well as for low-income elderly and disabled persons. The Secretary may request assistance from the Secretary of Health and Human Services in preparing the materials, which will be submitted for comment before being sent to State agencies. The Secretary will provide State agencies with information on the special nutrition program for women, infants, and children. State agencies will then provide child care institutions with materials explaining the benefits of health care coverage under Medicaid and the special nutrition program. The Secretary will provide State agencies with information on the special nutrition program for women, infants, and children, including income limits and application details. Adult day care centers will receive materials explaining benefits under Medicaid and the special nutrition program. The Secretary will annually update institutions on income limits for special nutrition programs. Institutions must provide written information to parents on benefits and income limits for Medicaid and nutrition programs. The Secretary will ensure that adult day care centers provide written information to program participants annually, including details on benefits, income limits, and where to apply for benefits. Expanded eligibility for meal supplements for afterschool care programs under the National School Lunch Act is amended to include youths, children of migrant workers, and children with handicaps. Additionally, demonstration projects are initiated to improve food service for homeless children. Section 18(c) of the National School Lunch Act is amended to require the Secretary to submit a report to Congress detailing actions taken to serve homeless children, estimate the number not served, and provide a plan to expand the program. The Secretary will use funds to support nutrition counseling, assessments, and referrals for homeless pregnant women and individuals in specific programs. The Secretary will provide funding for programs supporting homeless pregnant women, pregnant women at risk of homelessness, homeless mothers with newborns, and guardians of abandoned infants. Approved programs may receive funding for specified purposes. Auditing and recordkeeping requirements will be imposed to monitor fund usage. Periodic reports to Congress will be made on referral and nutrition counseling programs. Nutrition education and training assistance will be provided for family day care home sponsors and day care center staff. Section 19(f) of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to require states receiving grants to use 20 percent of any excess amount to provide nutrition education and training to institutions under the National School Lunch Act for improving services under the child and adult care food program. The requirements in subparagraph (A) apply to States only if more than $10,000,000 is appropriated for this section in a fiscal year. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATES. This Act and its amendments take effect on the date of enactment, with special effective dates for specific sections on July 1, 1995, and October 1, 1995.
